title: Choosing Mercy
devotional:
Eliza had always been taught that mercy was a virtue, a noble trait to be strived for. Yet, in the cutthroat world of corporate finance, where she thrived, mercy seemed like a weakness, a liability. Years she spent climbing the ladder, sacrificing relationships and personal well-being, telling herself it was all for a greater purpose. Now, as a senior executive, she was faced with a difficult decision. A long-time employee, Thomas, had made a costly error, one that could impact the company's bottom line. The company's policy was clear: termination. Eliza knew Thomas; he was a dedicated worker, a family man with children to support. Dismissing him would be devastating.

Her colleagues urged her to follow procedure, to make an example of Thomas to deter others. They argued that sentimentality had no place in business. Eliza wrestled with her conscience. Could she reconcile her professional responsibilities with her personal values? Was mercy a weakness, or could it be a source of strength? She spent a sleepless night pouring over financial reports, exploring alternative solutions. She found a way to mitigate the damage caused by Thomas's error, allowing him to keep his job, albeit with a demotion and a performance improvement plan. When she announced her decision, her colleagues were surprised, some even disapproving. But Eliza felt a sense of peace she hadn't experienced in years. She had chosen mercy, not as a sign of weakness, but as an act of courage, aligning her actions with her deepest beliefs.

In the days that followed, Eliza witnessed a transformation in Thomas. He was humbled and grateful, working diligently to regain his position and prove his worth. His renewed dedication inspired others, creating a more positive and supportive work environment. Eliza realized that mercy, far from being a weakness, had unleashed a powerful force for good, benefiting not only Thomas but the entire company.
image_description: A winding path leading to a sunlit clearing in a dense forest.
insights: The story of Eliza reflects the tension between justice and mercy, a theme explored throughout the Bible. Micah 6:8 calls us to 'do justice, and to love kindness, and to walk humbly with your God' (ESV). Jesus exemplified mercy in his interactions with sinners and outcasts, demonstrating that compassion and forgiveness are central to God's character. The parable of the prodigal son (Luke 15:11-32) illustrates God's boundless mercy and his willingness to welcome back those who have strayed. Colossians 3:12-13 urges believers to 'clothe yourselves with compassion, kindness, humility, gentleness and patience. Bear with each other and forgive one another if any of you has a grievance against someone. Forgive as the Lord forgave you.'
prayer: Heavenly Father, I confess that I often struggle to extend mercy to others, especially when they have wronged me or fallen short of my expectations. Help me to see others through Your eyes, with compassion and understanding. Grant me the courage to choose mercy, even when it is difficult or unpopular. Fill my heart with Your love and enable me to forgive as You have forgiven me. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: Where in your life are you being called to extend mercy? Who needs your compassion and forgiveness? What steps can you take to cultivate a more merciful heart?
